user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of add_response_entry:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
add_response_entry (struct MHD_Response *response,
                    enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                    const char *header,
                    const char *content)
{
  size_t header_len;
  size_t content_len;

  if (NULL == content)
    return MHD_NO;

  header_len = strlen (header);
  content_len = strlen (content);
  return add_response_entry_n (response, kind, header,
                               header_len, content,
                               content_len) ? MHD_YES : MHD_NO;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function add_response_entry:
static bool
add_response_entry_n (struct MHD_Response *response,
                      enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                      const char *header,
                      size_t header_len,
                      const char *content,
                      size_t content_len)
{
  if (NULL == response)
    return false;
  if (0 == header_len)
    return false;
  if (0 == content_len)
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, '\t', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, ' ', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, '\r', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (header, '\n', header_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (content, '\r', content_len))
    return false;
  if (NULL != memchr (content, '\n', content_len))
    return false;

  return MHD_add_response_entry_no_check_ (response, kind, header, header_len,
                                           content, content_len);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
return MHD_add_response_entry_no_check_ (response, kind, header, header_len,
                                           content, content_len);
explanation: Other fragments were not reported because they do not present potential 8.13 issues: header and content are already declared as const char * (they are const-qualified), the local variables header_len and content_len are size_t (not pointers), the NULL checks and zero-length checks are control logic not pointer-type issues, and calls to strlen are to functions that accept const char * (no const-discard). The enum parameter and non-pointer scalar uses do not relate to pointer const-qualification. The listed fragments cover places where non-const pointers are declared or passed on (and where const qualifications might be discarded), so other code locations do not need investigation for Rule 8.13.
